importantArticles.headline: Tesla CEO Elon Musk weighed in on tariffs as well, indicating that while he doesn’t love the levies, the EV maker is in a good position to handle whatever President Donald Trump decides.  “Tariffs are tough on a company when margins are still low,” said Musk, adding he believes that Tesla is the least affected by tariffs among major auto makers.  “The tariff decision is entirely up to the president of the United States…I will weigh in with my advice,” said Musk, adding he believes lower tariffs are generally a good idea.
importantArticles.title: 'Tariffs Are Tough,' but Tesla Is Least Affected, Musk Says

importantArticles.headline: The integration of digital technology is transforming the EV battery electrical testing equipment market, facilitating real-time diagnostics and more precise testing methodologies. As battery technology progresses, manufacturers are investing in sophisticated testing equipment for battery cells, modules, and Battery Management System Hardware-in-the-Loop (BMS HIL) simulations to ensure safety, performance, and reliability. Key industry players are driving market growth internationally,...
importantArticles.title: Electric Vehicles Today - Digital Revolution Drives Battery Testing Advancements

importantArticles.headline: Tesla (NASDAQ: TSLA) stock has declined 41% year to date, making it one of the 10 worst-performing companies in the S&P 500.  Shares initially soared when Donald Trump won the presidential election in November.  CEO Elon Musk spent over $250 million to support his campaign, so investors assumed Tesla would benefit under the Trump administration.
importantArticles.title: Tesla Stock Investors Just Got Good News From CEO Elon Musk, but Q1 Earnings Were a Disaster

importantArticles.headline: Listening to President Trump on Tuesday, it's as if all the vitriol towards Fed boss Jay Powell - the threats, the name calling - was some crazy misunderstanding.  Trump now says he had "no intention of firing him" and was just gently angling for a rate cut or two.  In the same news conference, Trump said the exorbitant levies on Chinese goods following a rapid tit-for-tat trade war escalation - so high that the actual numbers became irrelevant - will soon be "substantially" lower.
importantArticles.title: Morning Bid: Trump's Fed backflip sets off relief rally

importantArticles.headline: SHANGHAI (Reuters) -China's annual auto shows have become the world's premier showcase for the rise of ever-cheaper, high-tech electric vehicles from domestic brands in the world's biggest car market.  But the Shanghai auto show opened on Wednesday amid industry-wide uncertainty over how the U.S.-China trade war could sap demand and upend supply chains as about 70 automakers launched more than 100 new models into a crowded market with more losers than winners.  Automakers also wrestled with a Chinese government crackdown, announced last week, on the marketing of smart-driving systems that many industry executives view as the next technological battleground here.
importantArticles.title: Trade war, safety concerns take centre stage at Shanghai auto show

importantArticles.headline: Musk offered no evidence for his claims but described the protests as “natural blowback” on Tesla from those on the receiving end of the fraud.
importantArticles.title: Elon Musk claims Tesla demonstrators are somehow being paid via the government’s ‘waste and fraud’ — they just won’t admit it

importantArticles.headline: As US stocks (^DJI, ^GSPC, ^IXIC) sell off, Solidarity Capital CEO Jeff McClean sits down with Josh Lipton to check in on the "Magnificent Seven," made up of Nvidia (NVDA), Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL), Tesla (TSLA), Microsoft (MSFT), Amazon (AMZN), Meta (META), and Apple (AAPL). To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Asking for a Trend here.
importantArticles.title: How to trade the Magnificent 7 amid the market sell-off

importantArticles.headline: It fell out of the top 10 on Monday, according to Dow Jones Market Data.  Tesla hasn’t been out of the top 10 since June 11, 2024.  In June 2024, Tesla was worth about $544 billion, which was good enough for 12th place.
importantArticles.title: Tesla Is No Longer Among the 10 Most Valuable S&P 500 Companies

importantArticles.headline: Tesla  stock lost ground on Monday as investors responded to a pair of potentially negative developments.  Also, Tesla is being sued for allegedly speeding up its odometers to avoid warranty claims.  The question for investors is whether either will affect the stock.
importantArticles.title: Tesla Stock Is Falling. Odometers, Low-Price Cars, and Earnings Loom Over Shares.
